column4: All .. i have a backup script that runs every night that I need to run as root, is there a way to script becoming root at the start of it?
You run it from cron ?
akhanu yes
I'd say if the script itself is set with root:root ownership, there shouldn't be problems.
also, is it root's cron or some other user's cron ?
akhanu:  i guess i should say i have it running in kcron, i dont see any user based options there
ill set it up to run in cron then and see what happens. thanks
is kcron used systemwide or user speciffic? I don't know anything about kcron
akhanu: user based ..
then your srcipt will be run as beloging to that user. You have to make it belong to root's crontable ?
(drop the question marke there)
mark*
akhanu:  yep thats what im doing now :-D
thanks
When you open a terminal and type  "crontab -l" does anything appear ?
as user, not root
Akhanu: yeah i have the jobs scheduled by kcron
so  "crontab -l" reveals the line that starts the script, right ?
yes that is correct
akhanu:  45 17 * * * /backup.scr

What I'd do, is copy that line, save it somewhere temporary. Then remove the setting from your kcron configuration. Then get root access with "sudo bash".  And last, type "crontab -e" (as root this time) and paste there that line of before.
sweet thanks
after saving and opting out from "crontab -e" you'd have that same entry in the root's crontab, not the users.
WARNING! In the crontab line, put the full path of the script!
